block.p: ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. ''Fighting Dinosaurs: New Discoveries From Mongolia,'' featuring one of the most famous fossil finds in the world; through Oct. 29. ''Mongolia Observed: Photographs Present and Past,'' featuring 40 color images by Robert Peck and black-and-white photographs by the explorer Ray Chapman Andrews from the 1920's and 30's. Imax films are ''To Be an Astronaut'' and ''Dolphins.'' In the Imax Theater tonight and tomorrow night at 9, ''Laser Aerosmith in 3-D''; at 10, ''Laser Led Zeppelin.'' Laser show tickets: $12. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8:45 p.m. Admission (suggested donation): $10 for adults; $7.50 for students and the elderly; $6 for children. Combination tickets are available. Information: (212) 769-5100; advance tickets: (212) 769-5200.
ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. ''Fighting Dinosaurs: New Discoveries From Mongolia,'' featuring one of the most famous fossil finds in the world; through Oct. 29. ''Mongolia Observed: Photographs Present and Past,'' featuring 40 color images by Robert Peck and black-and-white photographs by the explorer Ray Chapman Andrews from the 1920's and 30's. Imax films are ''To Be an Astronaut'' and ''Dolphins.'' In the Imax Theater tonight and tomorrow night at 9, ''Laser Aerosmith in 3-D''; at 10, ''Laser Led Zeppelin.'' Laser show tickets: $12. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8:45 p.m. Admission (suggested donation): $10 for adults; $7.50 for students and the elderly; $6 for children. Combination tickets are available. Information: (212) 769-5100; advance tickets: (212) 769-5200.

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY'S ROSE CENTER FOR EARTH AND SPACE, Central Park West at 81st Street. This 333,500-square-foot, seven-floor, 120-foot-high exhibition and research center includes the new Hayden Planetarium, the Cullman Hall of the Universe and the Gottesman Hall of Planet Earth. The Hayden Planetarium contains the Space Theater, presenting ''Passport to the Universe,'' and the Big Bang Theater, featuring narrated visual and audio effects simulating the beginning of the universe. ''Starry Nights: Fridays Under the Sphere,'' music tonight from 5:45 to 8 p.m. with Ron Affif, through July 28. Free with admission; food and cash bar. ''Full Moon: Apollo Mission Photographs of the Lunar Landscape,'' from NASA's Apollo missions to the moon; through Sept. 23. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays to 8:45 p.m. Space shows run throughout the day. Admission (suggested donation) to the American Museum of Natural History, which includes the Rose Center: $10; for students and the elderly, $7.50; children 12 and under, $6; under 2, free. Admission to the museum, the Rose Center and the Hayden Planetarium space show: $19; students and the elderly, $14; children 12 and under, $11.50; under 2, free. Information: (212) 769-5100. Reservations: (212) 769-5200.

HISTORIC RICHMONDTOWN, Staten Island Historical Society, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmondtown. More than 25 buildings from the late 17th to the 19th centuries, restored and furnished. This village and outdoor museum depict the history of Staten Island and the surrounding region. In ''Living History,'' during the summer season (through Sept. 1), costumed interpreters will demonstrate the skills and trades of their earlier counterparts, including the tinsmith, storekeeper and dollmaker; the focus this weekend is on recreation of the period, including games, toys and community get-togethers. The exhibition ''Toys!'' will run through December 2001. Guided tours are available. Hours through Sept. 1: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $4; the elderly and children 6 to 18, and students, $2.50; 5 and under, free. Information: (718) 351-1611.

MUSEUM OF JEWISH HERITAGE: A LIVING MEMORIAL TO THE HOLOCAUST, 18 First Place, at West Street and Battery Place, Battery Park City. Sunday from noon to 5 p.m., an outdoor Jewish music festival on the museum's east lawn. Free with museum admission. Also throughout the day, workshops focusing on Jewish musical traditions, melodies and instruments will be offered in the museum. Performers include Hasidic New Wave, Yale Strom's Hot P'stromi, Adrienne Cooper, Elias Ladino Ensemble, Neshama Carlebach and Zalmen Mlotek. Artifacts, documents, photographs, videos and film clips are included in exhibitions on the Holocaust and on Jewish life before and after World War II. Other exhibitions: ''Children of a Vanished World: Photographs by Roman Vishniac,'' through Oct. 20. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m.; Fridays and the eves of Jewish holidays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; closed Saturdays. Admission: $7; students and the elderly, $5; children 5 and under, free. Tickets can be bought in advance through Ticketmaster, (212) 307-4007, or by calling the museum on the day of the visit, (212) 945-0039. Information: (212) 509-6130.

NATIONAL MUSEUM OF THE AMERICAN INDIAN, Alexander Hamilton United States Customs House, 1 Bowling Green, Lower Manhattan. ''Reservation X: The Power of Place,'' multimedia installations by seven artists, through Aug. 20. Tomorrow at 11 a.m. and 2 p.m., stories and dolls workshop with Donna Shakespeare-Cummings on the traditional and contemporary Arapaho dolls. Sunday at 11 a.m. and 2 p.m., a slide presentation and workshop led by artist Fellow Shonto W. Begay on Native American cultural influences on painting projects. Daily screenings in the video viewing room begin at 1 p.m. and are repeated on Thursdays at 5:30 p.m. Hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m. Free. Information: (212) 514-3888.
Gardens

BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN, 900 Washington Avenue, Prospect Heights. Through Sept. 16, butterfly and hummingbird trails open for tours, with related crafts and other activities on weekends. The Japanese Hill and Pond Garden has recently opened, with guided tours available. Admission: $3; $1.50 for students and the elderly; free for children 15 and under; free on Tuesdays, except holidays; free from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 8 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. The conservatory closes 30 minutes before the grounds. Information: (718) 623-7200.

NEW YORK BOTANICAL GARDEN, 200th Street and Kazimiroff Boulevard, Fordham, the Bronx. The grounds include more than 47 specialty gardens and plant collections. The Exotic Courtyard Garden is open through Sept. 24. Today, a daylily sketching class; call (718) 817-8747 to register. ''Cool Off,'' in the Ruth Rea Howell Family Garden Tuesdays through Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. in July, featuring summer flowers in full bloom and activities for children. Saturdays and Sundays at 12:30 p.m., 90-minute bird and butterfly walks. Garden and summer Adventure Garden hours: Tuesdays through Sundays and Monday holidays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Botanical garden admission: $3; students and the elderly, $2; children 2 to 12, $1; under 2, free. Grounds admission free for all on Wednesdays and from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. There are combination packages. Parking: $5.Information: (718) 817-8700.

WAVE HILL, West 249th Street and Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx. Gardens, greenhouses and woodlands are part of the 28-acre garden and cultural institution. Sunday at 5 p.m., ''Dances for Wave Hill,'' featuring Nai-Ni Chen Dance Company, Guta Hedewig and Terry Dame and the Junkyard Gamelan, with Jenny Romaine. Free with admission. Tomorrow at 2 p.m. at Garden Garage, a garden workshop on herb topiaries, including a short walk around the gardens. Materials fee: $7. Call extension 215 to register. Tuesdays through Sundays, 9 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; Saturdays, free until noon. Information: (718) 549-3200.
Cruises

CIRCLE LINE CRUISES, leaving from Pier 83, 42nd Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. A two-hour 24-mile cruise around southern Manhattan passing landmarks like Ellis Island and the United Nations, daily at 11 a.m., 2 p.m. and 4:30 p.m. Tickets: $20; children 12 and under, $10; the elderly, $16. A three-hour 35-mile cruise around all of Manhattan, daily at 9:30, 10:15 and 11:45 a.m., 12:30, 1:15, 2:45 and 3:30 p.m. Tickets: $24; children 12 and under, $12; the elderly, $19. ''Harbor Lights,'' daily at 7 p.m. Tickets: $20; children 12 and under, $10; the elderly, $16. ''The Beast,'' 30-minute speed boat ride in the harbor, daily, every hour on the hour, 11 a.m. to dusk, except Wednesdays, when it is 2 p.m. to dusk. Tickets: $15; children 5 to 12, $10. Information: (212) 563-3200.

CIRCLE LINE SEAPORT CRUISES, leaving from Pier 16, South Street Seaport at the East River, Lower Manhattan. One-hour cruises around Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty, Mondays through Fridays at noon, 1:30, 3 and 4:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays at noon, 1:30, 3, 4:30 and 6 p.m. Prices: $12; children 12 and under, $7; the elderly, $10. The Beast, a 30-minute speedboat ride. Saturdays and Sundays, hourly from 11 a.m. to dusk. Tickets: $15; children 12 and under, $10. Information: (212) 630-8888.

WORLD YACHT, leaving from Pier 81, 41st Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. Daily dinner cruises along the West Side of Manhattan and around New York Harbor, from 7 to 10 p.m., boarding at 6 p.m. Prices: Fridays, $75; Saturdays, $79; Sundays, $67 (does not include beverages, taxes or gratuities). Brunch cruises sail on Sundays from 12:30 to 2:30 p.m., with boarding at 11:30 a.m. Price: $39.95. Information: (212) 630-8100.

N.Y. WATERWAY, leaving from Pier 78, West 38th Street and 12th Avenue, Manhattan. Daily two-hour full Manhattan cruise, at 10:30 a.m. and 1:30 p.m., through Nov. 12. Tickets: $24; $19 for the elderly; $12 for children ages 3 to 12; 2 and younger, free. Daily, a 90-minute cruise of New York Harbor; at 10 a.m., 11 a.m., noon, 1 p.m., 2, 3 and 4 p.m. Tickets: $19; the elderly, $16; ages 3 to 12, $9; 2 and younger, free. Fridays at 10:15 p.m., disco cruise. Price: $19; $9 for children. A 70-minute twilight tour leaves daily, except Tuesday, at 8:45 p.m.; additional tours on Saturdays at 7:15 and 10:15 p.m. and on Sundays at 7:15. Tickets: $19; the elderly, $16; children, $9. Information: (800) 533-3779.
EVENTS

ANNUAL BASTILLE DAY CELEBRATION, 60th Street between Fifth and Lexington Avenue. With a music and dancing tonight at 9 at the Pierre Hotel, Fifth Avenue and 61st Street; tickets, $20. Sunday, from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., ''Bastille Day on 60th Street.'' Free. Sponsored by French Institute Alliance Francaise, the French-American Chamber of Commerce and the Committee of French-Speaking Societies. Information: (212) 355-6100.

''CITY THAT DRINKS THE MOUNTAIN SKY,'' Wagner Park, Battery Park City, Lower Manhattan. The story of the city's water supply told with puppets, music and poetry, in a free performance by the Arm-of-the-Sea Theater. Tomorrow at 7 p.m. Sponsored by the Battery Park City Conservancy. Information: (212) 267-9700.

KMART EAST RIVER FESTIVAL, Astoria Park, 23rd Avenue and 19th Street, Queens. Tomorrow, 2 to 7 p.m. Sponsored by the City of New York Parks and Recreation, the Urban Park Rangers and the Greater Astoria Historical Society. Information: (888) 697-2757.

PATHMARK MULTICULTURAL ARTS FESTIVAL 2000, Kips Bay Boy and Girls Club, 1930 Randall Avenue, at White Plains Road, South Bronx. A free event featuring gospel, Afro-Caribbean and Latin music and dance with an appearance by the group Los Hermanos Moreno. Tomorrow, 1 to 6 p.m. Information: (888) 486-4656.

''SUNSET JAM ON THE HUDSON,'' Wagner Park, Battery Park City, Lower Manhattan. Featuring a rotating trio of percussionists: Mary Knyshok, Peter Hawes and Pamela Patrick. Tonight at 6:30. Free. Sponsored by Battery Park City Parks Conservancy. Information: (212) 267-9700.

MOONDANCE, Pier 25, Hudson River at North Moore Street, TriBeCa. Free music and dancing Sundays at 6:30 p.m. through August. This time, tango with Tanguardia. Sponsored by the Hudson River Park Trust. Information: (212) 533-7275.
ON THE STREET
WALL STREET COMMUNITY DAY FESTIVAL, from South to Water Streets, Lower Manhattan. Today, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by Community Board No. 1.
BLEECKER STREET FESTIVAL, from Avenue of the Americas to Seventh Avenue, Greenwich Village. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Sponsored by Our Lady of Pompeii Church.
MADISON AVENUE SUMMERFEST, Madison Avenue from 35th to 42nd Streets. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Israeli Civil Rights Education Fund.
AVENUE OF THE AMERICAS SUMMERFEST, 23rd to 33rd Streets. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Church of St. John the Baptist.
SUNNYSIDE KIWANIS FESTIVAL, Greenpoint Avenue from 44th to 48th Streets and on 46th Street, Queens. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Sponsored by the Sunnyside Kiwanis Club.
WALKING TOURS

''MILLIONAIRE'S MILE: THE UPPER EAST SIDE.'' Explore this neighborhood of private clubs, palatial homes and cultural institutions. Meets today at 1 p.m. at the General Sherman Statue, 59th Street and Fifth Avenue. Fee: $10; $8 for members, students and the elderly. Sponsored by the Municipal Art Society. (212) 935-3960.

''IMMIGRANT NEW YORK.'' A multiethnic walking tour of the Lower East Side, Chinatown, Little Italy and other ethnic neighborhoods. Meets today at 1 p.m. on the southeast corner of Broadway and Chambers Street. Fee: $12; students and the elderly, $10. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. Information: (212) 439-1090.

GREEN-WOOD CEMETERY, Brooklyn, covers the history and architecture of the ''City of the Dead,'' as well as the noted people buried there, including Louis C. Tiffany. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. at the entrance at Fifth Avenue and 25th Street, Sunset Park. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. Fee, $12; $10 for students and the elderly. Information: (212) 439-1090.

''JAZZ NIGHTS IN HARLEM.'' A tour of the area, followed by dinner and a stop at a jazz club. Meets tonight and tomorrow at 8 on the northeast corner of Lenox Avenue and 125th Street. Fee: $45. Sponsored by Harlem Heritage Tours. Reservations: (212) 280-7888.

''HELL'S KITCHEN HIKE'' tours the Midtown Manhattan area now known as Clinton. Meets tomorrow at noon on the northeast corner of Eighth Avenue and 48th Street. Fee: $5. Sponsored by Adventure on a Shoestring. Information: (212) 265-2663.

SUTTON PLACE, ROOSEVELT ISLAND AND ISAMU NOGUCHI GARDEN MUSEUM. A five-mile tour that begins in Manhattan, continues with a tram ride and visit to Roosevelt Island, and stops in Long Island City, Queens. Meets tomorrow at 11 a.m. inside Greenacre Park, on East 51st Street between Second and Third Avenues. Fee, $3. Sponsored by the Outdoors Club. Information: (212) 348-5344.

MEXICAN FOOD AND CULTURE OF SUNSET PARK, Brooklyn. A look at the area's markets and restaurants. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. at the corner of Fourth Avenue and 45th Street. Sponsored by the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment. Fee, $8; $6 for Center members; $5 for students and the elderly. Information: (718) 788-8500, extension 401.

''THE FULL MENU, AN OVERVIEW TOUR IN TWO PARTS,'' Lower Manhattan. Notable dining spots, as well as those with historical significance. The tour does not include food. Tomorrow and Sunday at 11:45 a.m. and 2:15 p.m. Fee, $11 for first part, $5 for second. Sponsored by Gotham Walk. Information and meeting place: (212) 629-1886.

''HAUNTED GREENWICH VILLAGE.'' The tour includes stops at the Hanging Elm, the site of the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire and a ''haunted'' firehouse, town house and restaurant. Meets Sunday at 4:30 p.m. on the southwest corner of Eighth Street and Fifth Avenue. Fee: $5. Sponsored by Adventure on a Shoestring. Information: (212) 265-2663.

''MORNINGSIDE HEIGHTS: CULTURAL DELIGHTS,'' Manhattan. Explores the numerous academic and religious institutions in the area. Meets Sunday at 2 P.M. on the northwest corner of Amsterdam Avenue and West 110th Street. Fee, $10. Sponsored by Bernie's New York. Information: (718) 655-1883.

''HISTORIC HARLEM.'' A tour that emphasizes the history, architecture and culture of the area, with stops at the Abyssinian Baptist Church, Striver's Row and sites associated with Zora Neale Hurston and Langston Hughes. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. in front of the Schomburg Center, at the northwest corner of Lenox Avenue and 135th Street. Fee, $10; $8 for students and the elderly. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. Information: (212) 439-1090.

HISTORIC (OLD) NEW YORK CITY WALKING TOUR, Lower Manhattan. Includes the financial district, Fraunces Tavern, the Vietnam Memorial and Battery Park. Meets Sunday at 2 p.m. on the northeast corner of Fulton Street and Broadway. Fee, $10. Sponsored by New York City Cultural Walking Tours. Information: (212) 979-2388.

JOHN F. KENNEDY JR. MEMORIAL TOUR. A bus and walking tour of important places during his life. Meets Sunday at 9 a.m. in front of Romantica Restaurant, 373 Fifth Avenue, near Empire State Building. Fee, $45. Sponsored by Dr. Phil: New York Talks and Walks. Information: (888) 377-4455.

THE OTHER LOWER EAST SIDE. A tour of the Kehila Kedosha Janina Synagogue, home to the Romaniote Jewish community from Greece. Sunday at 1 p.m. Sponsored by the 92nd Street Y. Fee, $18. Information and meeting place: (212) 996-1100.

HARLEM GOSPEL TOUR. A tour that includes stops at a church and several cultural institutions. Meets on Sunday at 10 a.m. on the southwest corner of Lenox Avenue and 116th Street. Fee: $20. Sponsored by Harlem Heritage Tours. Information: (212) 280-7888.

''ROCKEFELLER CENTER: ART AND ARCHITECTURE BETWEEN THE WARS.'' The history of this Art Deco monument, from the 1930's to the present. Led by Francis Morrone, an architectural historian. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. in the courtyard of the Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue at 51st Street. Fee: $15; $12 for members. Sponsored by the Municipal Art Society. Information: (212) 935-3960.

''FROM PAGES TO PAVEMENT,'' Manhattan. Includes locations mentioned in seven novels set in the gaslight era. Meets Sunday at 2 p.m. at the arch in Washington Square. Fee: $10. Sponsored by Street Smarts N.Y. Information: (212) 969-8262.

''TRIBECA: THE CREATIVE EXPLOSION.'' A look at an area that was transformed from an estate into an industrial center and then into a chic enclave. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. in Duane Park, at the intersection of Duane and Hudson Streets. Fee: $12. Sponsored by Joyce Gold History Tours of New York. Information: (212) 242-5762.
